Award.AwardTitle: Evaluating the Effect of Large-Format Stereoscopic Displays on Student Learning in Introductory College Physical Geography Classes
Award.AbstractNarration: Stereoscopic displays are now common in movie theatres, are available for home televisions, and are increasingly being found in higher education classrooms. Although 3-D stereoscopic images can generate great excitement, a key question is whether they truly provide educational benefit to the student. This research proposes to examine this question by comparing the effectiveness of 3-D stereoscopic images with 3-D non-stereoscopic images in introductory physical geography classes at both the University of Kansas (KU) and Haskell Indian Nations University (HINU). During the first year of the research, 3-D instructional material will be developed that is appropriate for introductory physical geography classes and this material will be used to teach classes at both schools using non-stereoscopic images. In the second year, the 3-D material will be utilized to teach these same classes, but the material will be presented stereoscopically. The effectiveness of non-stereoscopic and stereoscopic presentations will be compared by analyzing student responses to questions posed in class and on exams, for example by measuring the speed and accuracy of answering multiple choice questions, and by analyzing the quality of responses to essay and diagram questions. In addition, individual interviews will be conducted to examine the learning behavior of successful and poor learners, and focus groups will be used to evaluate the impact of these displays on the 5-10% of those who cannot see stereo. By testing at both KU and HINU, it will be possible to examine the role that cultural differences might play in the perception and usefulness of stereoscopic material. Due to high enrollments in introductory physical geography courses, the proposed research promises to impact the learning of tens of thousands of students in geography courses in higher education. More generally, by extrapolating the experimental results to courses outside of geography and to the K-12 environment, there is the potential to impact millions of students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stereoscopic displays provide geoscience instructors the ability to teach students the fundamental, and inherently three-dimensional, components of landforms and landscapes; yet the prevalence of such displays in higher education is limited. A variety of reasons, including prohibitive cost and unrealized education benefit, has limited the utilization of stereoscopic displays in higher education, though, in recent years, costs have dropped dramatically and new research has recognized the educational benefit of such systems, thereby making them a viable new tool for geoscience education. The overall purpose of our project was to determine whether the use of stereoscopic images enhances student learning in introductory physical geography classes. Our specific intent was to determine whether stereoscopic (3-D) images lead to more effective learning than when equivalent non-stereo images are used. We evaluated the effectiveness of stereo in several introductory physical geography classes at both the University of Kansas (KU) and Haskell Indian Nations University (Haskell).

 

Data from this project suggest that the answer to our primary research question is not as cut-and-dry as it seems. If fact, data from this project suggest that the presentation of images in stereo has differing effects when used for differing topics. Data from one of studies investigating seating location supports improved learning when using Google Earth as a stereo delivery method for at least one topic, whereas no effect was documented for non-Google Earth images. Similarly, data from another study using a 3-D television suggests a significant improvement in learning for the final exam for students who viewed content in stereo versus non-stereo. Conversely, however, data from our other studies suggests that stereo may negatively impact learning due to refocused attention away from student note taking. Likewise, data from the Haskell study does not support improved learning when viewing in stereo. In general, our results indicate that stereo presentation of concepts does not overwhelmingly improve student learning when compared to traditional non-stereo presentation. This statement should be qualified, however, as the classroom setting is ultimately un-controlled making testing our overall hypothesis difficult.

 

There are several other significant outcomes of this research. For example, seating angle should be considered in either the design of a new classroom to be equipped with a stereoscopic display or when choosing an existing classroom to be retrofit with this technology. This is especially true when lecture material is presented using interactive presentation software (i.e., Google Earth). Additionally, we have developed approximately 100 non-Google Earth images and 18 Google Earth files (kmz. files), which we plan to make freely available through a KU hosted webpage so that teachers can use our created images in their classrooms. Some of these sample images are linked to this report.
